data.title: Homepage
data.text:
ENTER impacts the socialization process of young people by incorporating the idea of Jewish peoplehood into their lives through formal and informal education. A growing consensus has emerged that by improving literacy, building knowledge and expanding opportunities for experiential learning—both in Israel and across the Jewish world—we can bolster solidarity, mutual responsibility and respect. A core aspect of Jewish peoplehood is the belief that we are part of one extended family, and through our efforts we believe this spirit can be nurtured and deepened. We are investing in formal education (school systems), informal education (youth movements, camps, experiential learning) and public education (traditional and social media).

Our in-house data mapping points to a significant disconnect between researchers and operators, and the difficulty in yielding overarching lessons given the wide variety of methodologies and approaches in use. The “Jewish peoplehood index” – or set of indices – will identify trends, better distinguish sub-group variation, assess both attitudes and behaviours, and expand the measurement of interventions. Moreover, such data would provide a more nuanced, evidence-based understanding of the broader stresses and strains in Israel-Diaspora relations. To view the recommendations from our Jewish Peoplehood mapping project click here. For the full report, please click here.

Dare to Ask is a series of online videos that aims to offer insight into the lives of different communities and break down stereotypes while answering the questions people are afraid to ask. During the first season, Israelis answer questions regarding topics such as Judaism as a whole, American in the eyes of Israelis and more.

This simple and unique format allows for dealing with light and breezy questions alongside hard and tricky ones. The pilot season offers a unique insight to conflicting Israeli issues by showcasing a variety of different opinions and people tackling the same issue. By talking about taboo issues in such a manner, we can better understand tricky and complex situations in Israel and allow people to form their own opinion on the matter ahead.

Click here to watch the full trailer. To watch the episodes – click here.

Dare to Ask is a join initiative between ENTER and The Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County.

ENTER’s One2One cross-cultural exchange, in partnership with RootOne, an initiative of The Jewish Education Project, and the Israeli Ministry of Education, allows young people to meet for a series of curated 1:1 video encounters focused on Jewish peoplehood.

The One2One program is an opportunity for Jewish high schoolers to connect around shared interests and Jewish life. One2One seeks to build connections between Jewish high schoolers from Israel and around the world. By raising awareness of Jewish values like “mutual responsibility” (arvut hadadit in Hebrew), the program aims to build a sense of Jewish peoplehood. To learn more about One2One, please visit here.

ENTER’s “Peoplehood Infused Schools” initiative, a collaboration with the Israeli Ministry of Education, Jewish federations, private donors, and the Jewish Agency, offers a certification for Israeli public schools that adopt an integrated set of values and programs designed to raise awareness about World Jewry. This initiative addresses a major gap, especially in the majority secular state-supported system (Mamlachti), where levels of Jewish peoplehood awareness are particularly low. The initiative is designed to complement more formal curriculum-based projects introduced in recent years by government ministries and national institutions. The program is based on a 5 pillars model which is implemented in each school based on its unique characters. Click here to learn more about the program.

ENTER initiated and co-sponsored a field mapping survey in Israel, to better understand its’ emerging Jewish Peoplehood professional ecosystem. The mapping effort is designed to improve the collective understanding of who is leading the Jewish Peoplehood field in Israel, how deeply this work is penetrating into Israeli society, and where gaps may exist. Over a period of six months, nearly 350 Israeli professionals representing over 60 organizations were surveyed. The findings of the mapping are available through a technological platform, and enable organizations to update their programs and projects and maintain a current, relevant snapshot of the sector at any given point in time. The findings and recommendations were presented at a major gathering of peoplehood professionals. The event, led by lead researcher Dr. Ezra Kopelowitz, and representatives of all the co-sponsors, included a keynote address from Dr. Nachman Shai, Minister of Diaspora Affairs.

Alon Friedman is the Founding Executive Director of “ENTER: The Jewish Peoplehood Alliance”.

Between 2012-2019 Alon served as head of the Israel office of Hillel International and as CEO of the Hillels of Israel, operating 8 campus centers across the country.

Prior to this position, Alon served as Associate Director of MASA Israel Programs (2008-2012), as the Executive Director of the WUJS Institute in Arad (2004-2008) and as a National Emissary (Shaliach), developing educational resources and cultivating pro-Israel activities among college students on North American campuses (2001-2004).

Alon began his educational career in 1994 as a group leader for summer programs in Israel. He is a frequent speaker on Jewish Peoplehood, Identity and leadership as well as Israeli society and culture.

Born in Tel-Aviv, Alon served as an officer in the IDF, holds an MA degree in Communications and Journalism from the Hebrew University and resides in Hod-HaSharon with his wife Joni and their 3 children.

At ENTER, Zohar Mandel serves as Associate Director of Strategic Partnerships.

Prior to joining ENTER, Zohar led the philanthropic partnerships at The Shahaf Foundation; a coalition of leading Israeli and international philanthropists, foundations and Federations, supporting mission-driven communities across Israel’s geo-social periphery. Zohar started her professional career at The Reut Institute, where she served for 5 years as an analyst focusing on Israel-Diaspora relations and as Director of the institute’s external relations.

Zohar is a graduate of the Nahum Goldman fellowship, an exclusive program uniting Jewish leaders from around the world. She holds a BA in Governance, Diplomacy and Strategy, and an MA in Communications and Government, both from the Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) in Herzilya.

Amanda Bekkerman is Vice President of The CRB Family Foundation, which supports a number of programs and organizations that are in the interest of its founder and chair, Charles Bronfman, a businessman, philanthropist and co-founder of Enter. Enter is an innovative start-up whose vision is to ensure the Jewish people remain a dynamic, diverse, global community that is united, secure and inclusive. In her role as ENTER’s manager of North American operations, Amanda supports its co-founders and CEO in managing communications with key partners in North America, develops reporting procedures, and reviews ongoing program planning as it relates to ENTER’s three focus areas: education, public awareness, and impact.

Roy Waks is the Director of Operations and Development at ENTER’s One2One program.

Prior to this role, Roy served as the Educational Development Manager at Unistream, an organization that trains youth from Israel’s socio-economic and geographic periphery towards entrepreneurship. He was responsible for developing effective pedagogical strategies, creating curriculums, developing content, and providing staff training.

Roy holds a Bachelor’s degree in Visual Communication from Shenker College of Design. He earned honors for his final project, “Zionist Movement,” which explored the relationship between ideology and body movement in contemporary Israeli youth.

Roy participated in research groups on performance in Israel and served as a research assistant at the Hebrew University. He has also worked as a teaching assistant at Seminar Hakibbutzim College, as a leading staff member at BIG IDEA Summer Camp, and as a Workshops & Events Coordinator at the Abraham Hostel in Jerusalem.

Shir Ben David is the Peoplehood Infused Schools’ Program Director.

Before joining the team, Shir worked as an educator specializing in topics of Jewish-Israeli identity and Jewish peoplehood. Shir is an alumnus of “The Israeli Scouts delegation to the USA”. and an alumnus of the “Atid” program- a year of service- Shnat Sherut. Thanks to these programs she was exposed to North American Jewish communities and to the great importance of maintaining a connection between Israel and the Jewish communities around the world, at an early age. She was the Israeli emissary in the Federation of Northern New Jersey, worked with various organizations\schools\synagogues of the Jewish community in this area. In addition, she coordinated and managed the educational activity of the Israeli scout tribe in the area. In her third year on the SHLICHUT, she was promoted to be the Director of education of the east-coast activity of “Tzofim Tzabar”. After returning to Israel, she continued to work under the worldwide department of the Israeli Scouts (“Tzofim Tzabar”) in Israel, as the head of the field of “”HAGSHAMA”, the program of the graduates of the movement who choose to go on a significant year in Israel -Shnat Sherut/Mechina program). After years of working in the informal education field, Shir was also a prima-class teacher and a teacher for Bible and Israeli-Jewish culture at a school in Tel Aviv. She has a bachelor’s degree and a teaching certificate in history , Israel’s Bible and Jewish-Israeli Culture.

Dan Meridor was Israel’s Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Justice, Minister of Finance and Minister of Intelligence, Secretary of the Cabinet and Chair of the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the Knesset. A graduate of the Faculty of Law of the Hebrew University and a practicing lawyer, he served in the IDF as a tank commander and fought the 1967 and 1973 wars. His rank is Ret. captain.

In addition to his role with ENTER, he serves as the Chair of the Board of Bezalel Academy of Art and Design, the President of Israel’s Council of Foreign Relations and the Chair of the Board of the Truman Institute of Peace.

Meridor is married to Dr. Leora Meridor, they have four children and twelve grandchildren.

Daniel B. Shapiro has devoted his career to advancing U.S. interests in the Middle East, including by strengthening the U.S.-Israel relationship and dedicating efforts to promote Israel’s security and peace between Israel and its neighbors. He has served as U.S. Ambassador to Israel (2011-2017), on the staff of the National Security Council, and in senior advisory roles in the U.S. Congress. He is currently an adviser to Israeli companies establishing and expanding their presence in the United States, and U.S. companies and organizations doing the same in Israel.

Molly Buckman currently serves as a Program Officer at The Diane and Guilford Glazer Foundation in Los Angeles and has been with the Foundation since 2019. At the Foundation, she works in partnership with organizations that enhance the development and sustainability of strong Jewish identities and communities, strengthen Israel-Diaspora relationships and those between Jews worldwide, address antisemitism and the delegitimization of Israel, and build positive relationships with diverse communities outside of the Jewish world. In addition, Molly’s grant portfolio includes social service work and medical research in Los Angeles and Israel.

Molly received an undergraduate degree from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, a Master’s in Social Work and Certificate in Jewish Communal Leadership from The University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Previously, Molly worked at Jewish Child and Family Services in Chicago as a mental health clinician in the Community Counseling Center in Skokie. In addition, she worked in the Synagogue Community Partnership as a community-based social worker where she focused on creating greater access to social services within synagogue communities. Following her time in Chicago, she moved back to her native LA and served as the Assistant Director of Leadership Development at the Jewish Federation of Greater Los Angeles, where she helped oversee the Community Leadership Institute for young adults and budding lay leaders.

Molly currently lives in Studio City with her husband and two sons.

Michal Grayevsky is President of JCS International, a Ronald S. Lauder company. A well-known senior media executive, communications strategist, and former investigative reporter, Ms. Grayevsky has over 30 years of experience at the intersection of politics, business, diplomacy and media. She previously served as Deputy Chairman of the Board of Channel 10, Israel’s second largest television channel and, as Chair of the Board’s Finance Committee. In addition to her role as Advisory Committee Member with Enter, Michal serves on the Board of Directors of the UN Women for Peace Association, the International Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the International Steering Committee of Limmud FSU.

Dr. Jeffrey R. Solomon is Senior Advisor to Chasbro Investments, the family office of Charles Bronfman. For two decades, he was the President of the Andrea and Charles Bronfman Philanthropies, a group of foundations operating in Canada, Israel and the United States. He currently sits on the Boards of the Jim Joseph Foundation in San Francisco and the KIND and Lubetzky Family Foundations in New York. He served as the Chair of Leading Edge, an organization aimed at talent acquisition and retention in the Jewish community and serves as Co-Chair of the Peaceworks Foundation.
